Chapter 26, Part 2: The Assembly of Bodhisattva SubÄhu
SubÄhu!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas fully practice the perfection of meditation?

If the eyes of a bodhisattva see forms, he does not grasp at their characteristics. Sometimes the eye faculty may be drawn by external conditions. He should practice correctly and guard it, not allowing it to follow conditions. He does not fix his mind on ignorance and attachment to the world, and he upholds this precept.
At that time, he fully attains the precept of the eye faculty.
The ears hearing sounds, the nose smelling fragrances, the tongue tasting flavors, the body experiencing tactile objects, and the mind cognizing dharmas are also like this.

Whether walking, standing, sitting, lying down, speaking the Dharma, or in silence, this bodhisattva never departs from a mind of tranquil concentration. He skillfully guards his hands and feet without distraction, always feeling shame and skillfully guarding his speech. He looks straight ahead with a peaceful gaze, his mind always tranquil, not delighting in jesting or laughter. He skillfully controls his bodily, verbal, and mental actions, causing them to be tranquil.
Whether in private or in public, there is no difference in their minds.
They are always content with the necessary things, such as clothing, food, bedding, and medicine, and are easy to support, easy to satisfy, and easy to employ.

They skillfully practice tranquility and avoid busyness and confusion. Their minds are unaffected by gain and loss, slander and praise, flattery and criticism, suffering and happiness. They are neither arrogant nor humble.
They have no different minds towards life and non-life, and are free from anger and love.
They regard enemies as if they were infants, and their minds are always impartial towards those who are patient and those who are not.
It is the same with the voices of sages and ordinary people, quiet and noisy sounds.

Their minds are neither arrogant nor humble towards hateful and beloved forms. They are free from attachment, anger, and love for the pleasant and unpleasant, and the same is true for sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects.
This bodhisattva observes desires as if they were bones and marrow, because of wrong thoughts they give rise to this mind.
They observe desires as if they were a mass of flesh, because of many resentments and hatreds.
They observe desires as if they were a torch, because they abandon happiness and cultivate the Dharma of suffering.
Contemplate desires as fruits on a tree, because many people are attached to them.
Contemplate desires as borrowed, because one has no control over them.ğŸ”½Contemplate desires as dreams, because they are momentary and fleeting.
Contemplate desires as boils, because one gives rise to the notion of pleasure in the midst of suffering and delusion.
Contemplate desires as hooks, because one engages in evil dharmas and falls into evil destinies.
Contemplate desires as an ash river, because one increases desire and defilement without knowing satisfaction.

Therefore, the bodhisattva, having contemplated in this way, is free from desires, evil, and unwholesome dharmas. With initial and sustained thought, he attains the joy and pleasure of separation, accomplishing the practice of the first meditation.

Free from initial and sustained thought, internally serene, with single-pointed mind, free from initial and sustained thought, he attains the joy and pleasure born of concentration, accomplishing the practice of the second meditation.

Free from joy, practicing equanimity, mindful and aware, with right cognition, his body experiences pleasure, and the sages are able to practice and let go, accomplishing the practice of the third meditation.
Letting go of pleasure and pain, ending sorrow and joy, practicing equanimity, mindful and pure, he accomplishes the practice of the fourth meditation.
Contemplating the thought of happiness towards all sentient beings, one accomplishes immeasurable and boundless thoughts of kindness.

Contemplating the thought of suffering towards sentient beings, one accomplishes immeasurable and boundless thoughts of compassion.ğŸ”½Contemplating the thought of joy towards sentient beings, one accomplishes immeasurable and boundless thoughts of joy.
Abandoning the thoughts of suffering and happiness towards sentient beings, one accomplishes immeasurable and boundless thoughts of equanimity.

This bodhisattva does not contemplate the thought of form, and accomplishes the practice of tranquility in the sphere of space.ğŸ”½Not contemplating the thought of space, one accomplishes the practice of tranquility in the sphere of consciousness.
Not contemplating the thought of consciousness, one accomplishes the practice of tranquility in the sphere of nothingness.
Not contemplating the thought of the sphere of nothingness, one accomplishes the practice of tranquility in the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.

This bodhisattva, regarding inhalation and exhalation, whether following or abiding, knows it is long when it is long, and knows it is short when it is short, and accomplishes the practice of tranquility in inhalation and exhalation.
This bodhisattva contemplates and observes the thought of impurity of the body, accomplishing the practice of tranquility of the thought of impurity.
This bodhisattva contemplates the thought of impermanence arising from birth, old age, and sickness, accomplishing the practice of tranquility of the thought of impermanence.
Contemplating the immeasurable faults arising from food, he accomplishes the practice of tranquility of the thought of impurity in food.

In the various worlds, cities, towns, and villages with various adornments, contemplating and discerning the thought of destruction, he accomplishes the practice of tranquility of the thought of the world being unenjoyable.ğŸ”½This bodhisattva internally having the thought of form, externally observing few forms, whether beautiful or ugly, grasping their characteristics, accomplishes the practice of the first stage of mastery.

This bodhisattva internally having the thought of form, externally observing many forms, whether beautiful or ugly, grasping their characteristics, accomplishes the practice of the second stage of mastery.

If this bodhisattva dies or is cremated, and the ashes are blown by the wind or exposed to the sun, carried away by water, or completely destroyed, or if he severs the three existences, this is called the third stage of mastery, the internal absence of form perception observing external forms as few, whether beautiful or ugly, grasping their characteristics.
This bodhisattva internally has no form perception but externally observes forms as many, whether beautiful or ugly, grasping their characteristics, accomplishing the fourth stage of mastery.

This bodhisattva internally has no form perception but externally observes blue forms as immeasurable and boundless, joyfully grasping their characteristics, accomplishing the fifth stage of mastery.ğŸ”½This bodhisattva internally has no form perception but externally observes red forms as immeasurable and boundless, joyfully grasping their characteristics, accomplishing the sixth stage of mastery.

This bodhisattva internally has no form perception but externally observes yellow forms as immeasurable and boundless, joyfully grasping their characteristics, accomplishing the seventh stage of mastery.
This bodhisattva, internally without form, externally observes white forms as immeasurable and boundless, loves and grasps their characteristics, and accomplishes the eighth superior sphere practice.
This bodhisattva enters this immeasurable and boundless universal sphere, not thinking of different characteristics, and accomplishes the first universal sphere practice.

This bodhisattva enters the immeasurable and boundless universal spheres of water, fire, wind, blue, yellow, red, white, space, and consciousness, not thinking of different characteristics, and accomplishes the ten universal sphere practices.

When this bodhisattva enters the dharma of suffering, the mind contemplates all wholesome roots, namely great kindness, great compassion, upholding the true Dharma, not cutting off the Three Jewels, adorning the Buddha's body, purifying the Brahma voice, the vows made in the past, teaching and transforming sentient beings, purifying the Buddha's world, sitting under the bodhi tree, turning the wonderful Dharma wheel, and eliminating the afflictions of all sentient beings. The objects contemplated by the mind are like this.

When this bodhisattva enters meditation, he leaves the four abodes of consciousness and does not rely on the great elements of earth, water, fire, wind, space, or consciousness. He also does not rely on this world or the next world. He enters such meditation without relying on anything at all.
This bodhisattva practices meditation with a mind of love and joy, in order to enter the unsurpassed liberation meditation.
This bodhisattva cultivates meditation, wishing to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation and to attain omniscience and perfect all the Buddha's teachings.
Whether contemplating or having contemplated, he wishes to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation and to attain omniscience and perfect all the Buddha's teachings.
If he is unable to practice meditation, this bodhisattva should contemplate in the following way:

'I should from time to time gradually increase my diligence and distance myself from a distracted mind, from time to time gradually increase my diligence in learning to concentrate the mind, causing this concentrated mind to increase and expand, and to the end of life never be lazy or give rise to sorrow.'

This bodhisattva arouses the mind of enlightenment, contemplates the mind of enlightenment, cultivates the mind of enlightenment, aspires to enlightenment, and seeks enlightenment. This is called the immeasurable and boundless concentration of wholesome roots of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, wishing to cause all sentient beings in all places in the world to give rise to uncontaminated concentration, give rise to the concentration of no more learning, give rise to uncontaminated concentration, and give rise to the concentration of no more learning.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices this concentration, does not consider it difficult, and takes it as a joy. He quickly and completely perfects the perfection of concentration.
SubÄhu!
How does the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva perfect the perfection of wisdom?
SubÄhu!

If there are wise and intelligent people who, having studied, are able to uphold it, and having heard it, recite and practice it, who are well-versed in the profound meaning of the Dharma and are also able to discern it, and who, having heard the Dharma, contemplate its meaning,
then the bodhisattva should then be close to them, respectfully make offerings, revere and praise them, and not abandon them even if it means losing one's life.

Because of studying, because of understanding the definitive meaning, because of contemplating the meaning, and because of making offerings and respecting the teacher and preceptor, the bodhisattva will not avoid suffering and distress even if it means losing one's life, such as hunger and thirst, cold and heat, mosquitoes and gadflies, poisonous bites, wind, sun, and other unpleasant touches, scolding and slander.

This bodhisattva generates the thought of a treasure trove towards the true Dharma, the thought of a precious storehouse towards the expounder of the Dharma, the thought of difficulty in encountering towards the listener of the Dharma, the thought of the life of wisdom towards the questioner of the meaning, the thought of wisdom towards the one with much learning who eliminates ignorance, and the thought of the wisdom eye born from hundreds of thousands of lives towards the discrimination of various dharmas.

This bodhisattva, having heard these dharmas, received and upheld them, cultivated and studied them, and widely discriminated them. Having known the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, the four noble truths, the twelve links of dependent arising, and the three times and three vehicles, he attained such knowledge.
How does one know the realms?
One knows two realms.
The conditioned realm and the unconditioned realm are called the two realms.
What is the conditioned realm?
If a dharma has arising, abiding, and ceasing, it is called the conditioned realm.
What is the unconditioned realm?
If a dharma has no arising, abiding, or ceasing, it is called the unconditioned realm.
This is called knowing the conditioned and unconditioned realms.
Furthermore, one knows the three realms: the wholesome realm, the unwholesome realm, and the indeterminate realm.
What is the wholesome realm?
If non-greed is accompanied by non-greed, if non-hatred is accompanied by non-hatred, if non-delusion is accompanied by non-delusion, this is called the wholesome realm.
What is the unwholesome realm?
If greed is accompanied by greed, if hatred is accompanied by hatred, if delusion is accompanied by delusion, this is called the unwholesome realm.
What is the indeterminate realm?
Excluding the wholesome and unwholesome, if there are other dharmas, this is called the indeterminate realm.
Furthermore, one knows the three realms, namely the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm.
What is the desire realm?

Hells, animals, hungry ghosts, asuras, humans, the four heavenly kings, the thirty-three heavens, the yÄma heavens, the tuá¹£ita heavens, the heaven of delight in creating, the heaven of freely partaking of others' creations.
If one is attached to desire, anger, delusion, and hopes in this realm, and the mind engages in activities, this is called knowing the desire realm.
What is the form realm?

Brahma Heaven, Brahma's Ministers Heaven, Brahma's Assembly Heaven, Great Brahma Heaven, Luminous Heaven, Lesser Luminous Heaven, Immeasurable Luminous Heaven, Luminous Sound Heaven, Pure Heaven, Lesser Pure Heaven, Immeasurable Pure Heaven, Universal Purity Heaven, Fruit-bearing Heaven, Lesser Fruit Heaven, Vast Fruit Heaven, Immeasurable Fruit Heaven, Formless Heaven, No Heat Heaven, No Affliction Heaven, Excellent Vision Heaven, Excellent Observation Heaven, Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven.
If one is attached to form, deluded, and hopes to attain the mind's activities in this realm, this is called the form realm.
What is the formless realm?
Space-like Heaven, Consciousness-like Heaven, Nothingness Heaven, Neither Perception Nor Non-Perception Heaven.
If there is no form, defilement, ignorance, or desire to obtain in the mind, the actions that are done are called the formless realm.
These are called the three realms.
Furthermore, knowing the four realms - the desire realm, the form realm, the formless realm, and the unconditioned realm - is called knowing the four realms.

Furthermore, knowing the six realms - the realm of desire, the realm of anger, the realm of harm, the realm of renunciation, the realm of non-anger, and the realm of non-harm - is called knowing the six realms.
Furthermore, knowing the six realms - namely, the realms of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness - is called the six realms.
Contemplating the earth element as impermanent and changing, without solidity or firmness, if it is impermanent then it is suffering, and if it is suffering then it is non-self.

The water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements are impermanent, changing, without solidity or firmness. If they are impermanent then they are suffering, and if they are suffering then they are non-self.
This is called knowing the six realms.
This bodhisattva, having heard such teachings, upheld and practiced them extensively, and then understood the five aggregates.
Namely, the aggregate of form, the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, the aggregate of mental formations, and the aggregate of consciousness.

Form is like foam on water, arising and ceasing, unable to endure for long.ğŸ”½Feeling is like a water bubble, arising and ceasing, unable to endure for long.ğŸ”½Perception is like a mirage, arising and ceasing, unable to endure for long.
Mental formations are like a plantain tree, arising and ceasing, unable to endure for long.
Consciousness is like an illusion, arising and ceasing, unable to endure for long.
This is called understanding the five aggregates.
This bodhisattva, having heard this teaching, upheld and practiced it extensively, and then understood the internal sense bases.
Namely, the eye sense base, the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases - these are called the six internal sense bases.
The eye sense base is the dharma of suffering, the dharma of aging, the dharma of death, emptiness, no self, and no possession of self, and it inflames the three poisons.

Birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress can also burn the dharmas of suffering and distress. The ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind are also like this, burning the three poisons up to all suffering.
This is called knowing the six internal sense bases.

Next, knowing the six external sense bases, the forms seen by the eyes are called the six external sense bases. The sounds heard by the ears, the smells smelled by the nose, the tastes tasted by the tongue, the tactile objects felt by the body, and the dharmas cognized by the mind are called the six external sense bases.

The forms seen by the eyes are the external sense bases. They are of an unstable nature, without support, and also without power. All are impermanent, as they are, not otherwise, like an illusion, like a magical creation.

The sounds heard by the ears, the smells smelled by the nose, the tastes tasted by the tongue, the tactile objects felt by the body, and the dharmas cognized by the mind are also like this. This is called knowing the six external sense bases.
This bodhisattva, having heard such dharmas, upheld and practiced them extensively. Having distinguished them, he then knew the four noble truths.

Namely, the noble truth of suffering, the noble truth of the accumulation of suffering, the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, and the noble truth of the path. These are called the four noble truths.
What is the noble truth of suffering?
If it is the five aggregates, the six elements, the six internal sense bases, and the six external sense bases, this is called suffering.
This suffering is impermanent, like an enemy, like a boil, like an arrow, like being imprisoned, like a broken vessel, it is not independent and therefore is without self.
Having attained such understanding, this is called knowing the noble truth of suffering.
What is the noble truth of the accumulation of suffering?
Namely, greed, anger, delusion, conceit, and the exclusive grasping of self, definitely reckoning the self as permanent, abiding, and indestructible.
The self is form, the self is different from form.
The self is perception, the self is different from perception.
The self is neither perception nor non-perception, the self is different from neither perception nor non-perception.
The self is the aggregates, the self is different from the aggregates.
The self possesses the aggregates, the aggregates possess the self.ğŸ”½The self is the elements and sense bases, the self is different from the elements and sense bases.
The self is within the realms and sense bases, and the realms and sense bases are within the self.
The self is the same as feeling, the self is different from feeling.
The self is the same as cognition, the self is different from cognition.
The self is without feeling, the self is different from without feeling.
The self is of little form, the self is different from little form.
The self is of much form, the self is different from much form.
The self is permanent, the self is impermanent.
The self is both permanent and impermanent, the self is neither permanent nor impermanent.
The self has a limit, the self is limitless, the self has both a limit and is limitless, the self has neither a limit nor is limitless.

After death, the self goes like this, after death, the self does not go like this, after death, the self both goes like this and does not go like this, after death, the self neither goes like this nor does not go like this.
Life is the same as the body, the body is the same as life.
From where does this sentient being come, and where does it go?
These sentient beings are then annihilated and not continuous, with self-action and self-experience, and other-action and other-experience.
Those who conceive of self have self-possession, and those who have self-possession have self.
Thus, they grasp the view of self and the view of the body, whether it be fetters, afflictions, self, or self-possession.

I accept the root of greed, anger, and delusion, whether it be the karma of body, speech, and mind, meritorious karma, sinful karma, karma of the desire realm, or karma of the form and formless realms. This is called the noble truth of the accumulation.
What is the noble truth of cessation?
If greed, anger, and delusion are exhausted, self and self-possession are exhausted, and grasping and existence are exhausted, this is called the noble truth of cessation.
What is the noble truth of the path?

If one sees the cessation of suffering and its origin, contemplates the faults of all conditioned things, sees nirvÄá¹‡a as tranquil, and has accomplished what was to be done, abiding in such a dharma, right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration, this is called the noble truth of the path.
Thus knowing the four noble truths, when this bodhisattva discriminates and contemplates the four noble truths, he sees conditioned dharmas as suffering, impermanent, empty, and without self.
He sees unconditioned dharmas as able to provide protection, as a home and a refuge. Although he makes such observations, he does not realize nirvÄá¹‡a.
Thus knowing the four noble truths.
This bodhisattva, having heard such dharmas, received and upheld them, cultivated and studied them extensively, and then immediately knew the twelve links of dependent origination.

Namely, ignorance conditions formations, formations condition consciousness, consciousness conditions name-and-form, name-and-form conditions the six sense bases, the six sense bases condition contact, contact conditions feeling, feeling conditions craving, craving conditions grasping, grasping conditions becoming, becoming conditions birth, birth conditions old age and death. This is called the twelve links of dependent arising.
If one does not know or see the four noble truths and the twelve links of dependent arising, this is called ignorance.
If there are bodily, verbal, or mental actions, whether meritorious, unwholesome, or bound to the desire, form, or formless realms, this is called formations.
If there is mind, thought, or consciousness, this is called consciousness.
If there are feeling, perception, volition, contact, or applied thought, this is called name.

If there are the four great elements and form derived from the four great elements, from the kalala stage up to the fully developed sense faculties, whether form that is created or not created, this is called form.
Because of the combination of name and form, it is called name-and-form.
If there are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind, this is called the six sense bases.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If the eye conditions form and generates eye-consciousness, the combination of the three dharmas gives rise to contact, which is called contact.
If there is the experience of suffering, pleasure, or neither suffering nor pleasure, this is called feeling.
If there is attachment, this is called craving.
If there is attachment to views and precepts, this is called grasping.
If there is form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, this is called existence.
If this existence gives rise to, this is called birth.
If this existence decays, this is called old age.
If this existence perishes, this is called death.

The bodhisattva thus contemplates and discerns the twelve links of dependent origination. He sees and hears that the earth is not the self and does not give rise to attachment, the self is not the earth and does not give rise to attachment, and also does not hope for it.
Water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness are also like this.
He sees and hears that nirvana is not the self and does not give rise to attachment, the self is not nirvana and does not give rise to attachment, and also does not hope for it.
This bodhisattva sees that all dharmas arise from causes and conditions, understands the three gates of liberation, and extensively studies and sees all dharmas as empty, signless, and wishless.
This bodhisattva sees that all dharmas arise from causes and conditions, understands the bliss of quiescence, diligently studies and extensively analyzes, and then ignorance ceases.

When ignorance ceases, then karmic formations cease. When karmic formations cease, then consciousness ceases. When consciousness ceases, then name-and-form cease. When name-and-form cease, then the six sense bases cease. When the six sense bases cease, then contact ceases. When contact ceases, then feeling ceases. When feeling ceases, then craving ceases. When craving ceases, then grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, then becoming ceases. When becoming ceases, then birth ceases. When birth ceases, then old age and death cease.
In this way, although the bodhisattva observes the arising and cessation of the twelve links of dependent origination, he does not realize cessation.
The bodhisattva thus knows the twelve links of dependent origination.

This bodhisattva, having heard this Dharma, single-mindedly accepts and upholds it, cultivates and studies it, and having extensively distinguished it, immediately understands the three times, namely the past, future, and present.
What is the past time?
If a dharma has already arisen and ceased, this is called the past time.
What is the future time?
If a dharma has not yet arisen or occurred, this is called the future time.
What is the present time?
If a dharma has arisen but not yet ceased, this is called the present time.
This bodhisattva recollects the unwholesome roots in the past, despises and detests them, and turns away from them.
In the future, unwholesome roots will lead to receiving unwholesome karmic fruits, which are not joyful, not lovable, and not agreeable.
In the present, unwholesome roots should be prevented from arising.
This bodhisattva is able to protect the actions of body, speech, and mind, as well as the six sense faculties, and always gives rise to wholesome actions without interruption.

In the past, the wholesome roots of the bodhisattva's mind of enlightenment, the exclusive mindfulness of enlightenment, the aspiration for enlightenment, the desire to attain enlightenment, the deeply cherished love and joy, and the vow to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation and attain omniscience, in order to perfect all the Buddha's teachings,
are also like this in the future and present worlds. Always not apart from this mind, never lazy, forgetful, or negligent.
If the aggregates, sense bases, and elements of the past world are already extinguished, unreal, non-existent, without self or possessions.
If the aggregates, sense bases, and elements of the future world have not yet arisen or occurred, they are without self or possessions.
If the present aggregates, sense bases, and elements are momentary and do not abide.
Why is it so?
The dharmas of the world do not have a single moment of abiding.
If there is a single moment, in that single moment there is also arising, abiding, and ceasing, and that arising, abiding, and ceasing also do not abide.

Just as there are internal and external aggregates, realms, and sense bases in birth, abiding, and cessation, these internal and external aggregates, realms, and sense bases also have birth, abiding, and cessation.

If one does not abide in this way, then it is not the self and not what belongs to the self.ğŸ”½If the past world has ceased, is unreal, does not exist, is not the self and not what belongs to the self.
If the future world has not yet arisen and has not yet occurred, it is not the self and not what belongs to the self.
If the present world does not abide moment by moment, it is not the self and not what belongs to the self.
If one sees the three worlds as not the self and not what belongs to the self, this is called true wisdom.

Not seeing the self and what belongs to the self as the self and what belongs to the self, this is practicing non-self and non-what belongs to the self in all existences, practicing the thought of detachment, practicing the thought of cessation, and practicing the thought of extinction. Although one practices in this way, one does not realize nirvana.
This is called knowing the three worlds.
This bodhisattva, having heard this Dharma, upheld and practiced it extensively, and having distinguished it, immediately knew the three vehicles.
Namely, the celestial vehicle, the Brahma vehicle, and the noble vehicle.
What is the celestial vehicle?
The first dhyÄna, the second dhyÄna, the third dhyÄna, and the fourth dhyÄna, this is called the celestial vehicle.
What is the BrahmÄ vehicle?
Loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, this is called the BrahmÄ vehicle.
What is the noble vehicle?
Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration, this is called the noble vehicle.

This bodhisattva sometimes cultivates the celestial vehicle, the BrahmÄ vehicle, and the noble vehicle, teaching sentient beings to abide in the three vehicles. At that time, he himself does not realize liberation. This is called knowing the three vehicles.
Furthermore, knowing the three vehicles refers to the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle, the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, and the Great Vehicle.
What is the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle?

Those of dull faculties attain liberation, in a single thought they leave behind the three abodes of existence, they delight in leaving the world and attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, they see the place of quiescence, and they diligently apply effort as if putting out a fire on their head.

If one who has not yet understood the Four Noble Truths wishes to shoot the target of the Four Truths with the arrow of wisdom, wishes to realize and understand with deep desire and diligence, this is called the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle.
What is the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle?

Those of middling faculties who wish to attain tranquility and dwell alone in a place, benefiting themselves and entering the concentration of tranquility, skillfully contemplating the twelve links of dependent arising, wishing to attain the Pratyekabuddha path and realize the Pratyekabuddha, this is called the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle.
What is the Great Vehicle?

Those of superior faculties who wish to liberate all sentient beings, to attain liberation, to attain omniscience, to perfect all the Buddha's teachings, the six perfections, to benefit all worlds, to end the suffering and distress of all sentient beings, who do not even value the five desires and pleasures of all worlds, let alone the immeasurable sufferings of the world,

They wish to cause sentient beings to uphold the unsurpassed precepts, to hear and see the Mahayana scriptures, to receive and uphold them, to cultivate and study them, to contemplate and discern them, to recite them and make them proficient, and to diligently apply themselves.

If there are bodhisattvas who cultivate the four means of conversion, they should go and draw near to them, wishing to cause sentient beings to embrace true wisdom and abide in the four means of conversion.
They always wish to hear the profound essentials of the Dharma, to receive and uphold them, and to discern them.

They wish to cause all to enter into meditation, to abandon their own happiness and benefit sentient beings, and to use their own power to follow the desires of others and cause them to abide in the Three Vehicles.
Although they perform such transformations, they always abide in the unsurpassed path themselves, their minds unshakable like vajra.
They always wish to attain unsurpassed enlightenment. Wishing to seek enlightenment is called the Great Vehicle.
This is called knowing the Three Vehicles.
When the bodhisattva hears this Dharma, receives and upholds it, cultivates and studies it extensively, and discerns it, he then knows the skillful means.
Taking refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha with one's whole body and mind, this is its function, vowing for the unsurpassed path.

Thus taking refuge and giving rise to the mind of enlightenment, whether walking, standing, sitting, lying down, eating, drinking, washing, or bathing, in these matters there is no other thought, but only the vow for unsurpassed enlightenment, always practicing and learning in this way.

This bodhisattva, whether just entering concentration or having entered concentration, always vows for all sentient beings to attain liberation, in order to attain omniscience and perfect all the Buddha's teachings, to be the honored one in the world, to tame all sentient beings, to be invincible among all sentient beings, to attain the most excellent, to teach and admonish all sentient beings, to enable all sentient beings to attain tranquility, to attain perfect enlightenment in all dharmas.
If a bodhisattva practices all wholesome roots, he wishes that all sentient beings will have no fear, leave the three evil paths, extinguish immeasurable suffering, and cut off all afflictions.
He wishes that those in the present and future who wish to attain the pratyekabuddha vehicle will be fully endowed with it.
He wishes that those in the present and future who wish to attain the great vehicle will be fully endowed with it.

He wishes to invite all Buddhas in the world in the present and future to abide in the world for one eon and expound the Dharma, enabling the assembly of sages to be harmoniously united while the Buddha is in the world.
This bodhisattva thinks like this:

'Wherever there are sentient beings who cultivate wholesome roots, whether wishing to be born in the human realm or heavens, or abiding in the Å›rÄvaka vehicle or pratyekabuddha vehicle, or loving speech, generosity, benefiting, and practicing together, I wish that they will be fully endowed with it.'
Because of this Dharma, the bodhisattva recites and chants it in the three periods of time and contemplates this Dharma.
Namely, I now take refuge in all the Buddhas, Dharma, and Sangha in all worlds, and bow my head in respect.
The majestic virtue of the Buddhas is invincible, and their appearance is extremely wonderful.

Bodhisattvas should always think like this: The Buddhas, Dharma, and Sangha should be in all places in the world without exception. Wherever there are directions, may there always be Buddhas. I wish to request them to remain for an eon, expound the subtle Dharma, and reprimand all evils.

If I have done so in the past or am doing so now, I have already become free from all evils. Even for a single moment, I wish to use all wholesome roots to enable all sentient beings to have immeasurable lifespans and abide in all wholesome dharmas.
May the bodhisattvas quickly turn the Dharma wheel, enabling the sages to attain precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.
May the Buddha's teachings always abide in the world and benefit sentient beings.
Those born in the five paths all attain wholesome roots, and even respectfully pay homage to the buddhas.
Always abide in this vow.
These are the wholesome vows of all bodhisattvas, enabling other sentient beings and themselves to attain wonderful and excellent spiritual powers.
If the treasures of the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha in all worlds of the future and present are to abide for an eon without any hindrances,
and if all bodhisattva treasures quickly enable the six perfections to be fulfilled, and quickly accomplish unsurpassed perfect enlightenment without any hindrances,

one wishes to enable all sentient beings to eliminate suffering, fear, and afflictions, and to engage in joy and happiness. Eliminate all unwholesome roots and accomplish all wholesome roots. According to one's wishes, accomplish the three vehicles and quickly accomplish the perfections. Have an immeasurable lifespan and attain liberation, accomplishing the unsurpassed path.
Up to respectfully paying homage to the buddhas, always make this vow.

This bodhisattva wishes to enable all sentient beings to end all suffering and distress. If all worlds in all places have buddhas up to the Dharma body, he wishes to offer his body to those buddhas, wishing to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation and accomplish the unsurpassed path, and to be born in a place where he reveres the Three Jewels.

With heavenly incense and flowers, he makes offerings to buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, and also makes offerings to the Dharma, the Saá¹…gha, and bodhisattvas, causing the treasures he offers to be like Mount Sumeru.
All sentient beings in all worlds, if they have needs, for the seven treasures, houses, clothing, food and drink, medicine, and bedding, he will provide them all without fail.

If there are those who delight in patience, vigor, and upholding the precepts, I will explain the Dharma to them according to their inclinations, enabling them to accomplish the supreme Dharma, causing the Three Jewels to be complete, practicing the six perfections, and quickly attaining Buddhahood.

They abandon all unwholesome dharmas, and with body, speech, and mind, practice the true meaning and wholesome conduct. They do not regress from bodhi and delight in bodhi. Wherever they go, they see buddhas and bodhisattvas and always learn wholesome roots. They establish sentient beings in wholesome dharmas.

These bodhisattvas know their own and others' wholesome roots, and aspire to wisdom and contemplate wisdom, wishing to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation and attain omniscience, and to be fully endowed with all buddha-dharmas.
These bodhisattvas, having aspired to and contemplated this, wish to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation and attain omniscience, and to be fully endowed with all buddha-dharmas.
These bodhisattvas, with such wisdom, if they are unable to learn, should contemplate in the following way:
I should now redouble my diligence, gradually cutting through ignorance little by little.

I will now redouble my diligence, gradually learning this wisdom from time to time, causing this wisdom to increase and become complete, and never be lazy or give rise to sorrow until the end of my life.

In this way, the bodhisattva gives rise to the mind of enlightenment, contemplates the mind of enlightenment, cultivates the mind of enlightenment, and aspires to the mind of enlightenment. This bodhisattva's wholesome wisdom is immeasurable and boundless.
Why is this?

This wisdom is the most supreme among all other wholesome wisdoms, causing all sentient beings in the world to give rise to immeasurable wisdom, give rise to the wisdom of no more learning, give rise to the wisdom of no outflows, and give rise to the wisdom of no more learning.
Good Arm!
In this way, the bodhisattva practices this wisdom, not considering it difficult but taking joy in it, and quickly perfects the perfection of wisdom.
After the Buddha spoke this sutra, the bodhisattva Good Arm joyfully praised, saying:
Excellent! Excellent!
He accepted it in faith and practiced it.
